DOC.HEAD: Iran Protests Deportation Of Students From Britain
With AM-Iran-Israel
DOC.TEXT: Iran protested to Britain on Wednesday about British plans to deport two Iranian students suspected of planning to kill Indian-born Salman Rushdie, author of the novel ``The Satanic Verses.'' Tehran television said Iran's Foreign Ministry sent an official protest to London through the Swedish Embassy, which looks after Iranian interests in Britain. Tehran also condemned the arrest of two other Iranians who were freed late Tuesday. Iran cut ties with Britain last February after Britain protested a death sentence imposed on Rushdie, a British citizen, by Iran's revolutionary leader, the late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini. Khomeini said ``The Satanic Verses'' blasphemed Islam, provoking a worldwide furor over the book. The four Iranians were arrested Friday under the Prevention of Terrorism Act, which gives police the right to hold them for seven days without charge. The Home Office said Tuesday that engineering students Karen Abrinia, 32, and Mehrdad Kokabi, 33, were being deported for ``reasons of national security.'' It did not elaborate. Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency quoted the students' lawyer, Zahir Aziz, as saying they believed they were arrested because they were suspected of planning to assassinate Rushdie, who remains in hiding. The two freed Iranians were identified as Hussein Gharibi and Javad Mousavi, 40, a disabled father of four children. Both IRNA and Tehran TV were monitored in Nicosia.
